titleStmt.title: Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire

body.head:
CHAP. XVI.
The Conduct of the Roman Government towards the Chriſtians, from the Reign of Nero to that of Conſtantine.
body.p:
I
F we ſeriouſly conſider the purity of the Chriſtian
religion, the ſanctity of its moral precepts, and the innocent as well as auſtere lives of the greater Chriſtianity perſecuted by the Roman emperors number of thoſe, who during the firſt ages embraced the faith of the goſpel, we ſhould naturally ſuppoſe, that ſo benevolent a doctrine would have been received with due reverence, even by the unbelieving world; that the learned and the polite, however they might deride the miracles, would have eſteemed the virtues of the new ſect; and that the magiſtrates, inſtead of perſecuting, would have protected an order of men who yielded the moſt paſſive obedience to the laws, though they declined the active cares of war and government.
